summary: A character reference letter written to Judge Alison Nathan on November 2, 2020, in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application. The author, a long-time family friend, attests to Maxwell's honesty, integrity, and lack of danger to the community, arguing she is not a flight risk and should be granted bail to prepare her defense.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The Honorable Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, to whom the character reference letter for Ghislaine Maxwell is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail application and character reference. The author describes her as a close, honest friend of decades, a prominent individual who will fight the charges and is not a flight risk or danger to children.

connections.description: Described as close friends for decades who met through family connections, socialized regularly, and remained in constant touch, speaking every year on Maxwell's birthday.

events.title: Bail Application Submission
events.description: The date the character reference letter was written and submitted to the court in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The author, a long-time family friend, provides a character reference asserting Ghislaine Maxwell's honesty, integrity, and that she poses no danger to children or the community.
The author states they would have "absolutely no hesitation in allowing Ghislaine to look after" their children, directly countering the allegations against her.
The author argues Maxwell is a prominent individual who will fight the charges, is not a flight risk, and should be granted bail to form a proper defense.
The letter mentions Maxwell has faced "monstrous allegations in the press" that forced her to worry about her safety.
The author offers to provide a financial surety to meet any bail pledge the court may set, indicating personal financial commitment to Maxwell's release.
